LORETTA AND RONNY AT THE TABLE WITH A BOTTLE OF WHISKEY
BOBO AND EDDIE STAND NEAR THE KITCHEN WATCHING
BLACK CREDITS ROLL AGAINST THE WHITE BACKGROUND.
PERRY AND THE SHY WAITER LOOK AT MR. JOHNNY AND LORETTA
ELSEWHERE IN THE LOBBY DURING INTERMISSION
PERRY, FEELING NO PAIN, COLLARS THE SHY WAITER
NOW WE SEE LORETTA FOR THE FIRST TIME
COSMO, THE HEAD OF THE FAMILY NOW, LIFTS HIS GLASS
THE FRONT DOOR OPENS AND THE OLD MAN AND THE DOGS COME OU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several dozen loaves of golden Italian bread are standing end in a shaft of morning sunlight. They are standing on in bins. In the window, ZITO'S can be read in reverse. We leave the loaves and DRIFT DOWN TO a Progresso Product calendar, which hangs from the wall by a nail. The month November. Various phone numbers and delivery dates have b penned in in a rough scrawl. Now WE GO TO a white formica counter, scuffed and pocked from long use. On the counter in a rinsed out olive jar filled with water, are three fa red roses. The TITLE APPEARS IN BLACK SCRIPT AGAINST THE  WHITE BACKGROUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now WE FAINTLY HEAR THE VOICE of Zito himself, and a low  TAPPING SOUND. SOME CREDITS ROLL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely discernable) Three times they cancel the order  with me, and three times they come  back. Who they kidding? They cheap,  cheap, cheap. The other bread they  get is no good. They save pennies.  Everybody complain and they come  back. "Zito, your bread is the best."  They're like children stupid in school  who cannot learn. The water. It's  the water. You buy bread in Hoboken,  you get Hoboken water. Hoboken water  is dry. Ask anybody who knows. Ask  your father. He knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During Zito's plaintive words, WE LEAVE the roses and MOV DOWN the counter TO a calculator being tapped very effici with the eraser end of pencil. When the results appear, t pencil notes the figure in a threadbare old ledger.

dialogues.speaker: NOW WE SEE ZITO
dialogues.text: He's a middle-aged Italian man with a kind face. But it's early in the day, and he's already been working for hours so he's a little tired and disgruntled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to make you some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: NOW WE SEE LORETTA FOR THE FIRST TIME
dialogues.text: She's entering a few final figures in the ledger. LORETTA Italian, 37. Her hair black, done in a dated style, is fl with grey. She's dressed in sensible but unfashionable cl of a dark color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you know about coffee? Gimme  a loaf of bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta emerges with her little weathered leather bookkee satchel and a loaf of Zito bread in a white paper bag. Sh moves off briskly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a little Italian funeral parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A generic little room filled with many flowers and wreath many folding chairs, a few OLD PEOPLE sitting and, up fro the star of the show, the CORPSE on display in his gold a formica casket. Before the casket is a little kneeler. We discover an OLD LADY there, who crosses herself and rises She goes and sits by RUBY, another old women. She leans o and says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Al Conti is a genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First WE SEE a name plate on a desk. The plate reads ALFO CONTI. We HEAR his VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SHOT WIDENS TO INCLUDE the loaf of bread which is hal cut up and being buttered. Next to the bread are two stea mugs of coffee. We HEAR the subdued TAPPING of Loretta's  tabulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're such an artistic genius,  why can't you keep track of your  receipts? How am I going to do your  income tax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am an artistic genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SHOT WIDENS and now we can see Al Conti and Loretta  sitting at the desk having Zito's buttered bread and mugs coffee. Loretta's got her calculator going and is enterin figures in Al's black, gold-lettered ledger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're an artistic genius, how  come you got butter on your tie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down and sees the stain. He's at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it here. I'll give you this,  Al, you make good coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She downs her coffee, accepts the stained tie which Al ha taken off, and slams the ledger shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking at a wall of dry-cleaned clothes bags. The are hanging from an automated grid. As we watch, the wall starts to move off to the left. A gap appears where no cl are hung. The gap creates visual frame. In the frame is  ROBERT. He is operating the grid with a little stick shif He stops it and takes down a garment. He leaves the frame heading off to the counter. When he moves away, WE SEE th Loretta is behind him, working her calculator, entering i ledger. She slams the ledger shut, waves goodbye, and goe After beat she reappears, produces Conti's tie, says some to Robert, who is out of view, leaves the tie, and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE SEE a cleaver whacking an oxtail into section. Now WE SEE Loretta, a few feet away, tabulating on a chop block that is partially obscured by a row of hanging rabb unskinned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long white box is being filled with red roses. We HEAR FLORIST'S VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red roses. Very romantic. The man  who sends these knows what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now WE SEE Loretta tabulating and the Florist working on box of roses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man who sends those spends a lot  of money on something that ends up  in the garbage can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Florist gives her a look and then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad everybody ain't like you,  Loretta. I'd be outta business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without me, you'd be out of business.  I like flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a sudden, brief, blinding smile. It's the f time we've seen her smile. She has gold work around one o her two front teeth. The Florist grunts and hands her a r rose. Camera moves close to Loretta and the rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red neon sign hangs in the window. It's a quaint downstairs restaurant in Greenwich Village. YOUNG COUPLE stop, look at the menu, become more interest in each other, kiss, and decide to go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White tablecloths and dark green walls, a tiny bar up by door. The WAITERS all look a little alike. That's because they're all related. The place is about half full, and bu along pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: A VIOLIN PLAYS a melancholy Neapolitan air. MR. JOHNNY and Loretta sit at a table for two talking qui They have their menus and glasses of red wine. Mr. Johnny Italian, around 42. His wavy salt-and pepper hair is  impeccably combed back; but there is so much that it thre to fall forward someday and engulf his face. He is wearin pinky ring, a dark suit, a gold watch, and, on his face, mustache and a look of incredible seriousness. Loretta is Italian, 37. Her black hair, done in a dated style, is fl with grey. She is wearing a dark blouse, black skirt, and high heels. One of her teeth is framed with gold work. Mr. Johnny is really timid of life, an overgrown boy, who hides these qualities behind a veil of dignity. Loretta is tough and efficient, loyal and watchful; she  watches out for Mr. Johnny, and defends him against life. BOBO, an Old World Italian waiter, comes over to take the order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Bobo. How are you tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Mr. Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will both have the Salad Ticino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll have the special fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want the fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the oily fish tonight. Not before  the plane ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him the manicotta, Bobo. Me,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mr. Johnny) That will give you a base. For your  stomach. You eat that oily fish, you  go up in the air, halfway to Sicily  you'll be green and your hands will  be sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) You look after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They HEAR a distinguished MAN'S VOICE rise out of the bab They turn and look. The man's name is PERRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry is a university professor. PATRICIA is his  girlfriend/student. He's in his 50's. She's about 25 year younger. She's getting her coat on in a huff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patricia, please don't go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think I am, a talking  dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just making a point about the  way you said... the way you stated  your aspirations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can kiss my aspirations!  Professor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She storms out, leaving Perry muttering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kiss my aspirations. Oh, very clever.  The height of cleverness. Waiter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An abnormally SHY WAITER stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you do away with her dinner,  and any evidence of her, and bring  me an big glass of vodka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But absolutely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SHY WAITER begins to efficiently clear.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNNY AND LORETTA EXCHANGE A GLANCE
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny is amused. Bobo serves them their salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man who can't control his woman is  funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was too young for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny considers this a point well taken.

dialogues.speaker: BOBO AND HIS NEPHEW EDDIE STAND NEAR THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Which can be seen through a serving window. They can look out over the restaurant tables. Bobo is melancholy and  philosophical. EDDIE is a young waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'samatter, Uncle Bobo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight Mr. Johnny's gonna propose  marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He arranged it with me. When he asks  her, then he'll wave to me and I'll  bring champagne. Good bachelor  customer for twenty years. But who  knows? Maybe he'll lose courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy duty stuff.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY, FEELING NO PAIN, COLLARS THE SHY WAITER
dialogues.text: He holds out his empty glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get another one of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I presume to ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am alone in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry lets go of his arm. He and the Shy Waiter commisera a moment. Then, wordlessly, the Shy Waiter goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBO IS CLEARING THE REMAINS OF MR. JOHNNY'S DINNER. He's already cleared Loretta's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Bobo. We'll take the check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want to see the dessert cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo goes. Loretta is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never have dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never is a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny is uneasy. He massages his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My scalp is not getting enough blood  sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta looks at him strangely. Bobo rolls up the dessert cart. WE SEE Loretta and Mr. Johnny through the frame of dessert cart. They turn and look at the desserts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have Something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo, take the cart away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Are you proposing marriage to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I was married and that my  husband died. But what you don't  know is I think he and I had Bad  Luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got married at the City Hall and  I think it gave bad luck the whole  marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right from the start we didn't do it  right. Could you kneel down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a good suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I helped you buy it. It came with  two pairs of pants. It's for luck,  Johnny. When you propose marriage to  a woman, you should kneel down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny slowly gets out of his chair. There's not enou room for him to kneel down. He has to ask two off-duty PR WRESTLERS who are eating dinner to move their chairs. The do so with bemused expressions. Their names are BOB and M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that man praying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Will you ma...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Where's the ring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at a loss) The ring?

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND MOOK ARE WATCHING MR. JOHNNY'S PERFORMANCE
dialogues.text: They are deadpan mugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mr. Johnny) A ring. That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I woulda sprung for a ring if it was  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got him on his knees. He's  ruining his suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could use your pinky ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like this ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You propose to a woman you should  offer her a ring of engagement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny takes off the ring and holds it out to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta. Loretta Castorini Clark. On  my knees. In front of all these  people. Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She meekly accepts the ring from him and takes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Johnny. Yes, John Anthony  Cammareri. I will marry you. I will  be your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny slowly stands up, brushes off his knees. The  restaurant has fallen utterly silent. Loretta smiles. The embrace. Loretta kisses him quickly.

dialogues.speaker: A MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN, SUSAN, IS MAUDLIN FROM THE PROPOSAL
dialogues.text: Bobo stands very near her table. She is about to applaud proposal. She brings her hands together. Bobo's hand flas out and neatly captures her hands before they can part ag The single sound dies abruptly in the silent room.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA AND MR. JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny is in control now. He looks around once, regal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo! The check!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I have just witnessed a  car accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shy Waiter sits down at Perry's table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was twenty-seven years old,  in Jersey City, I asked a woman to  marry me. She had red hair. She  smelled a jasmine. She wore black  shoes with pointy white tips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't hear me. She asked me to  repeat, so she could understand what  I said. But I wouldn't repeat it.  Outta shyness. So I'm a bachelor.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNNY AND LORETTA
dialogues.text: He's helping her on with her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we'll pick up the car, we'll make  the plane in plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny puts on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother will be happy I'm getting  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo approaches with the bucket of champagne. He's fluste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to bring the champagne, Mr.  Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to wave. We'll have it at  the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta driving and Mr. Johnny sitting beside her. In the back seat are two suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother is dying. When she is dead,  I'll come back and we'll be married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How near is she to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week. Two weeks. No more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's set the date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a month from today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must it be so definite? Can't we  just say that we will be married  when I get back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? At the City Hall? No! I want  the whole wedding or we will have  Bad Luck. For a whole wedding to be  planned, a date must be set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. A month. In a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A month from today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it, Johnny. I'll  take care of the whole thing. All  you have to do is show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dialogue on clip: (Close-up on Ava Gardner & Gregory kissing. Length of clip is 1:25)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're not going. You're staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shawfish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just across the bay, at the fuel  depot. The men wanted to try to get  home. I can't explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, I suppose the time has come  say it's been nice Dwight Lionel.  It's been everything. Oh, Dwight,  I'm frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I am so sorry for so many  things. I love you, Moira. I love  you. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many PEOPLE, most of them Italian, are lined up to board plane. A VOICE can be heard over the P.A. system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over P.A. System) International Flight Number Six-ohfour  boarding for Rome and Palermo at  Gate Twenty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me when you get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you when I get to Mama's  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made me very happy, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a piece of paper from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one thing about this wedding  I want you to do. Call this number.  It's a business number. Ask for Ronny.  Invite him to the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my younger brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't spoken in five years.  There was some bad blood. I want you  to call him and invite him to the  wedding. Will you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last call for  International Flight Number Six-ohfour  boarding at Gate Twenty-six for Rome  and Palermo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clumsily kisses her. Then he quickly turns and leaves. She waves, but he doesn't look back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT AIRPORT RUNWAY
dialogues.text: Close shot on plane's wheels and under belly as it slowly begins to move. Red lights are flashing.

dialogues.speaker: AN OLD ITALIAN CRONE IS LOOKING OUT THE TERMINAL WINDOW
dialogues.text: In the background we see the accordion like ramp that was loading to the departing aircraft, slowly fold up. Lorett walks up beside her, and looks out the window, too. The c is dressed in black and has a black scarf on her head. The Crone notices Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have someone on that plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (smiles) My fiancГ©.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have put a curse on that plane. My  sister is on that plane. I have put  a curse on that plane that it should  explode. Burn on fire and fall into  the sea. Fifty years ago she stole a  man from me. Today she told me that  she didn't even love him. She took  him to feel strong with me. Now she  goes back to Sicily. I have cursed  her that the green Atlantic water  should swallow her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in curses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Neither do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane takes off. Loretta looks after it anxiously. Al her hopes are on that plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LTD pulls into the entrance and Loretta gets out. An  ATTENDANT appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny's, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. The key's in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta walks of into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera frames the window with a sweetheart in neon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta walks up the street and enters the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta walks in. IRV and LOTTE, the middle-aged couple w own and run the place, are having an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen how you look at her and it  isn't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I look at her? (to Loretta) Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A split of Moet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to IRV) Like a wolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting the split) Like a wolf, huh? You never seen a  wolf in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Loretta) That's seven-fifty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta pays and waits for her change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen a wolf in everybody I ever  met and I see a wolf in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving the change) That makes ten. Thanks. Have a nice  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I see in you, Lotte?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl I married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotte, caught off-guard, blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big, old eccentric, three-story corner house. To o side, it's got a qated arch that leads to an inner courty where three cars could park. It's got two cast-iron balco About a third of the windows in the house are lit. From within can be HEARD the faint strains of VICKI CARR  SINGING and one DOG BARKING. Loretta appears, carrying  champagne, approaches the front door, unlocks it, and goe in.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: VICKI CARR is SINGING "IT MUST BE HIM." The front hall is typical of big old brownstones. There's big old oak coat rack with a built-in mirror and an umbre stand. There are several coats hanging from it. The floor littered with boots. There's also a side table. On the table is a large cut-glass bowl filled with a coup of pounds of hard candy. Loretta comes in and takes off her coat. A single MAD HOW is HEARD, followed by a PANDEMONIUM OF BARKING. FIVE DOGS charge into the hall to greet Loretta. They are totally  cockeyed, crackpot mutts. Their names are JUDAS, LUCY, LE FATBOY, AND JONES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, boys and girls. Guess what  happened to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VOICE of the OLD MAN is heard calling out from upstai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long must I wait? Quanto tempo  devo aspettare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Five Dogs turn away from Loretta and charge up the st toward the voice. Loretta walks toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the source of the Vicki Carr song, which is just  ending. COSMO CASTORINI, Loretta's father is just turning off the old stereo. He is a powerful man, about 65, with huge shock of white hair and gold wire glasses. He's wear a big old red silk robe over blue pajamas, and royal blue slippers. The room it filled with lumpy upholstered furni once grand, now threadbare; shawls and doilies cover hole in failing fabric. There's a fireplace containing a dying fire. Cosmo's wing chair, with his newspaper on it, is be a lit fringed lamp. Cosmo sees Loretta as she comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in his chair and puts his feet up on an old  needlepoint ottoman. He starts to read the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not sleepy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't sleep anymore. It's too much  like death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop, I got news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo puts down the paper and takes his feet off the otto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Let's go in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo gets up and heads for the kitchen. He hums and cont as Loretta opens champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta and Cosmo sit at the kitchen table. It's a big ti table with a black-and-white design. Loretta has put two fashioned champagne glasses on the table, the split of  champagne, a bag of sugar cubes, and a bottle of bitters. She pours the champagne, drops a little lump of sugar int each glass, and adds a dash of bitters. She hands one of drinks to Cosmo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. (She Toasts) Ti amo. (Translated: I love  you.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ti amo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did this once it didn't work  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What killed him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got hit by a bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Bad luck! Your Ma and I been  married fifty-two years an nobody  died. You were married, what, two  years, and somebody is dead. Don't  get married again, Loretta. It don't  work out for you. Who's the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Cammareri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him? He's a big baby. Why isn't he  here with you telling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's flying to Sicily. His mother's  dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More Bad Luck! I don't like his face,  Loretta. I don't like his lips. When  he smiles I can't see his teeth.  When will you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to come. You've got to  give me away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't give you away the first  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And maybe that's why I had the Bad  Luck. Maybe if you gave me away, and  I got married in a church, in a  wedding dress, instead of at the  City Hall with strangers standing  outside the door, maybe then I  wouldn't had the Bad Luck I had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have no wedding cake, no  reception or nothing. Johnny got  down on his knees and proposed to me  at The Grand Ticino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't sound like Johnny. Where's  the ring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta shows it. Cosmo examines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks stupid. It's a pinky ring.  It's a man's ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's temporary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is temporary. That don't  excuse nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll come to the wedding, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go tell your Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles. He doesn't. They rise from the table.

dialogues.speaker: THE CASTORINI HOUSE
dialogues.text: The door to the hall opens, and the light from without di illuminates a massive four-poster bed. Cosmo enters, foll by Loretta. He speaks into the dark a calm and measured  summons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose. Rose. Rose. Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lamp is switched on by the bed. By ROSE. Rose is in her 60'S, and is very, very beautiful. Her abundant white tre frame a face of porcelain delicacy. She's wearing an old and richly beautiful white nightgown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody. Loretta is getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again? Johnny Cammareri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo goes and sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not gonna marry him, Cosmo.  Do you love him, Loretta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. When you love them they drive  you crazy cause they know they can.  But you like him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. He's a sweet man. I wanna  have a big church wedding, Ma. And a  reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's gonna pay for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father of the bride pays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're rich as Roosevelt. You're  just cheap, Cosmo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo shouts from the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't pay for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't used to be cheap. He thinks  if he holds on to his money, he will  never die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's his duty as a father to pay for  my wedding, Ma ...

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: VICKI CARR, SINGING "IT MUST BE HIM", starts playing. Ros looks weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's gonna play that damn Vicki  Carr record. And then when he comes  to bed, he won't touch me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first golden rays of sunlight touch the great old hou The front door opens. Close shot of dogs coming into came as door opens. The OLD MAN comes out. The Old Man, who is Cosmo's father, is 83 years old. He is taking the Five Do out for their morning walk. He has their five leashes bun in one hand. In the other hand, even though it is a cloud November morning, he open black umbrella. He walks off do the block with the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man and the Five Dogs appear and enter the park. approaches a park bench where FELIX and LUCY are already  sitting. Felix and Lucy are about the same age as the Old Man. They each have a well-behaved DOG. When the Old Man  sits down, he lets the Five Dogs go. The Dogs run off, BA like mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wrong to just let them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Felix) Good morning, Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run around, they mess up the  whole park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do? Pick up  after five dogs? I'm eighty-three  years old. God in his heaven  understands that I cannot pick up  after five dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have too many dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogs can be HEARD in the distance. It sounds like the killing each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goes back to ignoring  Felix) Lucy. There are big things going on  in my house. My granddaughter Loretta,  the only daughter of my son Cosmo,  has engaged herself to be married a  second time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have heard that Johnny Cammareri  got down on his knees in The Grand  Ticino and proposed to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son does not like this Johnny  Cammareri. He says he is a big baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have one dog. Like Lucy.  Like me. I wish I hadda gun. If I  hadda gun, I would shoot four of  your dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man makes a low, threatening noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My granddaughter wants my son to pay  for the wedding. But he does not  want to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owes her a wedding from the first  time when there was none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. I don't know. He has not asked  my advice. If he asks my advice, I  don't know what I will say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the DOGS becomes intense again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't have to shoot those dogs.  They will kill each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so, huh, Stupid? Those  dogs love each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gates in the big archway are opened from the inside. It's Cosmo. He's wearing a good but old-fashioned suit, a overcoat, and a homburg. He's pulled his car, a 1965 blac Buick, up to the gate. Now that he has the gates open, he gets in the car and drives out to the curb. He gets out a goes back to lock the gates. As he does this, the Old Man approaches the house with the Five dogs and the open umbr The Old Man and the Dogs go to the front door of the hous Cosmo goes to the door of his car. The two men, father an son, see each other at the moment they grab their respect door handles. They each raise a hand in greeting; it is t same gesture for both men, an eccentric chopping motion. Then they open their respective doors. The Old Man disapp within the house. Cosmo drives slowly away in his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Receives a big lump of butter with a hissing gasp of  satisfaction. A wooden spoon pushes the sinking lump arou until the pan is coated. Two square slices of yellow brea with round holes punched in their middles land in the pan Two circles of green pepper land next to the bread. A spa flips over the bread which has become glistening gold on cooked side. Two eggs are broken and dropped sunnyside into the holes the bread. The circles of green pepper are pushed around by the spat scooped up deftly, and each is made to frame one of the e A WOMAN'S HAND garnishes each bright yellow yolk with a s of red pimento. The spatula reappears and lifts the resul from the pan, and slides them onto two small dark blue pl Now WE SEE that Loretta is just finishing setting the tin table for two. In the b.g., Rose is turning away from the big, old-fashioned six range gas stove where an old speck coffee pot is steaming up a sun-drenched window. Rose com toward the table with the laden blue plates. She's wearin nice old apron over a blue housedress. She's thoughtful. As Rose comes to the table, Loretta in a blue denim work  shirt and pants, goes to the stove and gets the coffee. A Rose puts breakfast on the table, she speaks to Loretta,  who's at the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop don't like Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta returns with the coffeepot to the table, and pour Then she takes the pot back to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we'll sell the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got married before, you didn't  sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta comes to the table. They sit down to breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma was still alive. Chiro was  still home going to school. Now he's  married and gone to Florida. If you  and Johnny moved in, had a baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thirty-seven years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's thirty-seven? I had Chiro  after I was thirty-seven. It ain't  over till it's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny has a big apartment. We'll  live there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we'll sell the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to stay, Ma. I love the  house. But Pop don't like Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WALL PHONE in the kitchen RINGS. Loretta goes and ans it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yea, this is Loretta Castorini -  yeah. Is that you Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny is calling on an old European-style phone. In b.g. is the sickbed. In the sickbed lies VESTA, Mr. Johnn mother, her grey hair spread out on a golden pillow. By the bed are THREE MOURNERS, old crones dressed in blac One clutches a missal, the other two clutch rosaries. All three are grieving in a steady low wordless whine. Mr. Jo speaks into the phone in a confidential manner. There is  some long-distance CRACKLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh, it's me. I'm calling from the  deathbed of my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your plane ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitresses were very nice. (glances over at his  mother) My mother is slipping away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to the Heavens) Quanto tempo devo aspettare? (now she aims more at  Johnny) How long must I wait?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't talk long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you told her we're getting  married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. I'm waiting till a moment  when she's peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR Loretta's VOICE over his receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just don't wait until she's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you called my brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you do it today? Call him, make  him come to the wedding. Five years  is too long for bad blood between  brothers. Nothing can replace your  family. I see that now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I'll call him. Today. Listen,  Johnny. Call me after you tell your  mother. Alright? Alright. And don't  stand directly under the sun. You've  got your hat, use your hat. Alright.  Bye-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta hangs up the phone. She thinks. Rose speaks from table, where she's still sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dying. But I could still hear  her big mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. That old lady makes him  sweat. (to herself) Where's that card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose gets up and takes the dishes to the sink, Loretta fi in her pocket and comes out with the business card Mr. Jo gave her. She dials the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who Are you calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (INTERCUT W/LORETTA IN KITCHEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISSY, a woman with a Queens accent, answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cammareri's Bake Shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Ronny there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. (yells into intercom) Ronny, the phone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (INTERCUT W/LORETTA IN KITCHEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is Ronny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling for your brother Johnny.  He's getting married and he wants  you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a long pause. Ronny's voice returns, hoarse with  emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't he call himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in Palermo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong can never be made right. (hangs up phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me come and talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta hangs up the phone. She looks at the card again,  makes a decision and pockets the card.

dialogues.speaker: THE TOWNHOUSE/INT. THE BUICK
dialogues.text: As Cosmo drives away. He's in a very good mood. He's  WHISTLING. He laughs to himself.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMARERI'S PASTRY SHOP
dialogues.text: And the street in front of it. Loretta arrives. She's wea a long, navy-blue cloth coat and a knit hat. She looks up the sign and at the business card in her hand, and enters the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a nice Italian bake shop. Three Italian women, CHRIS BARBARA, and MA wait on THREE WOMEN SHOPPERS at the count CHRISSY and BARBARA are in their late 20's or early 30's; is old, old. Loretta comes in and speaks to CHRISSY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Ronny Cammareri here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He down at the ovens. What do you  want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chrissy comes out and Loretta follows. They walk around t an outdoor staircase that descends into the sidewalk. Chr shouts down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, RONNY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slides open, revealing ROCCO, a baker missing a teeth. He is surrounded by bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody to see Ronny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocco slides back the door all the way. Chrissy and Loret make their way past him. He slides the door three quarter shut behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two coal-fired ovens, one at either end of the  room. There is a large wooden table roughly center. And  various pieces of baking equipment, dough-mixers, etc.,  scattered willy-nilly. And everywhere there is bread. PIETRO, a baker, is working at one of the ovens with a lo wooden spatula. RONNY is working at the other oven. Actually, he is just staring in the open door at the baki bread and burning coals. He's dressed in black jeans stre with flour, a white restaurant shirt, white cotton gloves and around his neck, a red handkerchief. He is black-hair handsome and intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny turns and takes in Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you come from my brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are going to marry my brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no life. My brother Johnny  took my life from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything in the oven room has stopped and everyone is  watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he's getting married. He has  his, he's getting his. And he wants  me to come? What is life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the wooden spatula and slides it into the ove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't come here to upset you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny slides a bunch of loaves out of the oven on the spa turns them around, and slides them back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say bread is life. So I bake  bread, bread, bread. (He's picking up loaves  of bread from one of  the boxes on the  floor, and casually  tossing them across  the room.) And the years go by! By! By! And I  sweat and shovel this stinking dough  in and outta this hot hole in the  wall and I should be so happy, huh,  sweetheart? You want me to come to  the wedding of my brother Johnny?!!  Where is my wedding? Chrissy! Over  by the wall! Gimme the big knife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ronny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara appears in the doorway and comes down the stairs  into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the big knife! I'm gonna cut  my throat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should come back another  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want you to see this! I want  you to watch me kill myself so you  can tell my brother on his wedding  day! Chrissy, gimme the big knife!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you I won't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Loretta) Do you know about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Cammareri!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is anybody's fault, but things  happen. (holds up his left  hand to Loretta) Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls off the glove. The hand is made of wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wood. It's fake. Five years ago  I was engaged to be married. Johnny  came in here, he ordered bread from  me. I put it in the slicer and I  talked with him and my hand got caught  cause I wasn't paying attention. The  slicer chewed off my hand. It's funny  'cause - when my fiancГ© saw that I  was maimed, she left me for another  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the bad blood between you and  Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that wasn't Johnny's fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care! I ain't no freakin  monument to justice! I lost my hand,  I lost my bride! Johnny has his hand,  Johnny has his bride! You come in  here and you want me to put away my  heartbreak and forget?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the big table, which is floured and covered wi bread. He sweeps everything off the tabletop during the n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it just a matter of time till a  man opens his eyes and gives up his  one dream of happiness? Maybe. Maybe.  All I have... Have you come here,  Stranger, Bride of my Brother, to  take these last few loaves from my  table? Alright. Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is bare. He stares at it blankly. He wanders aw to the back room where the flour sacks are kept. We hear single sob escape him from that room, and then silence. Everyone in the oven room looks after him. Then Chrissy  approaches Loretta. She holds the big knife at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the most tormented man I  have ever known. I am in love with  this man. He doesn't know that. I  never told him cause he can never  love anybody since he lost his hand  and his girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds out the knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Why don't you just kill him?  It would be so much more kind than  coming here and inviting him to a  wedding like he'll never have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta considers Chrissy, decides what she's going to do and goes to the flour room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many 50 lb. bags of flour are stacked under a bare electr bulb. A rough stone staircase opposite is lit by daylight from above. Ronny, quietly distraught, stands leaning by forehead against a stack of flour. Loretta approaches him She feels for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the stone staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows her up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta and Ronny emerge. He gestures. They enter the  apartment building behind the bakery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dark Italian coffee and dessert house. Reproductio of Roman statuary adorn grottos and alcoves. In the back a glass case displaying various desserts, and behind the  case, a big burnished gold cappuccino machine. The place almost empty.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: An album of "NEAPOLITAN FOLK SONGS" is PLAYING on the caf SOUND SYSTEM. The CAMERA TRAVELS along the face of an exposed brick wal DISCOVERING busts of Romans occasionally, and then IT COM TO the figure of COSMO. He's sitting at a table which is  inset into a nook, so we cannot see who he's with.

dialogues.speaker: DARK NOOK IN THE CAFE
dialogues.text: At a little table away from prying eyes, Cosmo sits with  MONA, his girlfriend. Mona is a pretty but overripe Itali woman in her late forties. She's all done up, and she loo at Cosmo with adoration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then there is copper, which is  the only pipe I use. It costs money.  But it costs money because it saves  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man understood me. The woman  wanted to be cheap, but the man saw  that I was right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have such a head for knowing.  You know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a small velvet box and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the box. It's a gold bracelet with a pattern of stars and birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Cosmo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are little stars and birds.  Birds fly to the stars, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three-story walk-up above Cammareri's Bakery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a two-bedroom apartment. The decor reflects Ronny's  love of the opera. The furniture is overstuffed, fringed the colors of Italian passion. But it is all a bit faded, the remains of an old flamboyance. The walls are decorate with opera posters; and over the fireplace there is a pai depicting a scene from "La Boheme": Mimi is standing in t snow. Ronny stares at the picture of Mimi in the La Bohem poster. Loretta comes in from the kitchen and sets down a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready for the coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta moves back into the kitchen. Ronny turns and watc as she walks down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta. What's that smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm making you a steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. I do what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it well done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll eat this bloody to feed your  blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU of Ronny's artificial hand, holding a fork stuck in a  steak. With his right he is cutting his steak. He switche hands and eats hungrily. Loretta watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is good. Uhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd Johnny find you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knew my husband who died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd he die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bus hit him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instantaneous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get engaged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny drops his knife and fork and turns away. Loretta is not surprised and does not move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) So. Five years ago your hand got cut  off and your woman left you for  another man. No woman since then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your husband get hit by the  bus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many men since then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Unlucky. I have not been lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about Luck, you  understand me? It ain't that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Do you think you're the only  one ever shed a tear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you talking to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any whiskey? How 'bout giving  me a glass of whiskey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOT OF COSMO & MONA IN THE BUICK The car has just come to a stop. We see Cosmo & Mona She exits car. Cosmo glances around with a slightly guilt look and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA AND RONNY AT THE TABLE WITH A BOTTLE OF WHISKEY
dialogues.text: Camera is close on Scotch being poured into two glasses. Loretta picks up her glass and swallows a healthy dose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was right to leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really are stupid, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta pours herself another shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know nothing about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was raised that a girl gets married  young. I didn't get married until I  was twenty-eight. I met a man. I  loved him. I married him. He wanted  to have a baby right away. I said  no. Then he got hit by a bus. No  man. No baby. No nothing! I did not  know that man was a gift I could not  keep. I didn't know... You tell me a  story and you think you know what it  means, but I see what the true story  is, and you can't. (she pours them both  another drink) She didn't leave you! You can't see  what you are. I can see everything.  You are a wolf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a wolf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big part of you has no words and  it's-a wolf. This woman was a trap  for you. She caught you and you could  not get away. (She grabs his wooden  hand) So you chewed off your foot! That  was the price you had to pay to be  free. (throws his hand down) Johnny had nothing to do with it.  You did what you had to do, between  you and you, and I know I'm right, I  don't care what you say. And now  you're afraid because you found out  the big part of you is a wolf that  has the courage to bite off its own  hand to save itself from the trap of  the wrong love. That's why there has  been no woman since that wrong woman.  You are scared to death what the  wolf will do if you make that mistake  again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you your life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you marrying Johnny? He's a  fool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have no Luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pounding on the table) He made me look the wrong way and I  cut off my hand. He could make you  look the wrong way and you could cut  off your whole head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am looking where I should to become  a bride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bride without a head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wolf without a foot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny stiff-arms everything off the dining table and grab Loretta. They kiss passionately. He pulls her up on the t and over the table to him. They are in each other's arms. They are on fire. Loretta pushes him away, gasping for ai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She changes her mind and lunges into another kiss. They s again after a long moment. They really haven't breathed. They both suck in air and look at each other in wonder an fear and passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like I'm falling! It's like I'm  in the ocean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss again. When they pull apart again, Loretta is  crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no Luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks her up in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh God. I don't care about  anything. I don't care about anything!  Take me to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carries her away, into the bedroom. MUSIC: "O SOAVE FANCIULLA", from "La Boheme." The MUSIC  CONTINUES THROUGH THE NEXT SCENE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny is laying her down in the bed. He is over her. They look into each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was dead, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. When they part there is a drop of blood on  Loretta's lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All my life I have never reached a  man. I knew that I would reach my  husband, but I took my time and he  was dead. Ronny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to cut you open and crawl  inside of you. I want you to swallow  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get all of me. Take everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're mad at him, take it out on  me, take your revenge on me! Take  everything, leave nothing for him to  marry! Hollow me out so there's  nothing left but the skin over my  bones. Suck me dry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Alright. There will be  nothing left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes are boiling with fierce animal tears. They hav opened their souls to each other and they are coming toge The MUSIC SWELLS to a terrible triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dog whines over exterior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With five beds for dogs. Four of the beds are empty and o the fifth Judas is whining. He looks around at the other  beds. Where is everybody? He goes out the bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: THE CASTORINI STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: Judas is running down the stairs and into the hall. We FO HIM down the hall. The hall is only dimly lit. He finds t four other dogs. They are crowded at a narrow doorway. From the doorway comes a golden light.

dialogues.speaker: THE PLEASED FACE OF COSMO THROUGH A VEIL OF STEAM
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK. We are in the Castorini dining room. Cosmo sits at the he of the table, a napkin tucked into his shirt. Rose has just laid down a massive platter of steaming bak fish. Already on the table is a platter of pasta, loaves bread, a big bowl of salad, two bottles of wine, and an  appetizer plate of salami and pimento. Seated at the tabl is COSMO, the Old Man, and RAYMOND and RITA CAPPOMAGGI. Raymond is rotund, moon-faced, bald, somewhere in his fif He has a pencil-thin mustache over his small mouth. His w Rita, looks very like him, except she has hair on her hea and none on her lip. Raymond is Rose's brother. There are two empty places at table, for Rose and Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Loretta? We're gonna start  without her.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE ENTRANCE WAYS TO THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: There is an accordion gate across it. Behind the gate, th Five Dogs stare at the people having dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be eating out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She don't know what she's missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like her not to call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she's got a lot on her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, can we talk about it, Rose?  Everybody's heard. She's getting  married again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Cammareri. I think it's great  and about time. What's she gonna do  with the rest of her life she don't  get married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man has piled his plate high with food. Now he st up, walks over to the Dogs, and puts the plate down in th midst. The Dogs attack the food and each other. The Old M walks back to the table and sits down. He looks down at t empty place in front of him, a little sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father needs a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose gets another plate from a sideboard and puts it in f of the Old Man. He immediately, methodically begins to fi his new plate. Rose goes to her place and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo. Many years ago, when they  told me you were marrying my sister,  I was happy. When I told Rose I was  marrying Rita, she was happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marriage is happy news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man laughs uproariously, subsides, goes back to  filling his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, pass the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never seen anybody so in love like  Cosmo back then! He'd stand outside  the house all day and look in the  windows. I never told you this cause  it's not really a story. But one  time I woke up in the middle of the  night cause this bright light was in  my face. Like a flashlight. I couldn't  think a what it was. I looked out  the window, and it was the moon! Big  as a house! I never seen the moon so  big before or since. I was almost  scared, like it was gonna crush the  house. And I looked down, and standing  there in the street was Cosmo, looking  up at the windows. This is the funny  part. I got mad at you, Cosmo! I  thought you brought this big moon  over to my house cause you were so  in love and woke me up with it. I  was half asleep I guess and didn't  know no better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were altogether asleep. You were  dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You were there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond stares at Cosmo, nodding, remembering. There's a  lull at the table, the SOUND of SILVERWARE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly angry) Well, what do you wanna talk about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita. Pass the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you drinking so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man gets up with his newly filled plate and heads for the Dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Man, if you give another piece  of my food to those dogs, I'm gonna  kick you till you're dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man reverses direction and heads back to his chai He sits down and starts to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the house is a great big full moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights in the bedroom are still on. Cosmo is in bed, his pajamas, asleep. Rose comes in her nightgown. She loo at Cosmo. He's snoring lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't stir. She goes to him and runs her hand throug his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drank too much and now you sleep  too hard, and later you'll be up  when you should be down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses his cheek. Then she turns out the lights. When the electric lights go out, moonlight floods the room. Sh goes to the window and looks out through the curtains at moon. Rose puts her face in her hands and quietly cries.

dialogues.speaker: MOON FROM CASTORINI HOUSE
dialogues.text: RESUME INT. CASTORINI HOUSE - MASTER BEDROOM - NIGHT (Ros crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom is flooded by moonlight. Loretta wakes up, a  little alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny wakes up, a little alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I think it's the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta goes to the window wrapped in a white sheet from bed. The window is glowing with moonlight. The moonlight  strikes her, and she is caught in its spell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny appears behind her, pulling on a robe. They speak i low voices, as if they were in church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen a moon like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes you look like an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and looks at him. They kiss. They break apart. Ronny looks up at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Looks like a big snowball.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE CAPPOMAGGI HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Shot of the house with the moon overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a big window right by the bed, and in the window the moon. Raymond and Rita are in their bed, asleep. Raym wakes up, and sees the moon in the window. He's stunned a excited, but he too speaks in this low voice of respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita. Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waking up) What? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Cosmo's moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, Raymond?  Cosmo can't own the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it's that moon I was talking  about at dinner. (looks through the  window, down into  the street) Is he down there? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is who down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would he be doing down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, in this light, and with  that expression on your face, you  look about twenty-five years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond smiles at her meekly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the house is still the great big full moon. The fron door opens and out comes the Old Man with the five Dogs. The Old Man is in a greatcoat and a felt hat, and he's sm a cigar. He stops on the top step and lets go a huge plum of cigar smoke. Then he starts off with the Dogs down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon and nothing else. Then a cigar is thrown into it and sends it shimmering. It was the moon reflected in wat Now the CAMERA PULLS BACK and WE SEE the Old Man and the  Five Dogs are standing on a ruined pier. The moon gleams from the Hudson River. The Old Man speaks to the Dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright now. Howl. Howl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dogs do not howl. So the Old Man, by way of demonstra howls at the moon. He looks to the Dogs to follow suit. T do nothing. He howls at the moon again. The Dogs do nothing. The CAMERA CONTINUES TO PULL BACK un WE CAN SEE the whole pier, with the Old Man and the Dogs it, and the moon above them. The Old Man, frustrated now, cries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long must I wait? Quanto tempo  devo aspettare!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dogs start to HOWL. The Old Man, pleased as the Mad H he is, laughs and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transition from moon reflecting in the water to dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning sun floods the room. Close on Loretta, she wakes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta jumps from bed, grabs her clothes to cover hersel and backs into closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What have we done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perturbed) Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from closet as she  hurriedly gets dressed) This time I was trying to do  everything right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he grabs a bathrobe,  pulls it on, puts it  on and moves towards  the closet.) Don't just become excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought if I stayed away from the  City Hall, I won't have that Bad  Luck I had again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're trying to make me feel guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm marrying your brother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'm guilty. I confess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're invited to the wedding! It's  in a few weeks. Why didn't you do  like him and be with your dying mother  in Palermo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't get along with anybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ruined my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible! It was ruint when  I got here! You ruint my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no I didn't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta emerges from the closet, tucking in her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, oh yes you did! You've got  those bad eyes like a gypsy! Why  didn't I see it yesterday! Bad Luck!  Is that all I'm ever gonna have? Why  didn't I just pick up a stone and  kill myself years and years ago? I'm  gonna marry him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night never happened, you hear  me? I'm gonna marry him anyway and  last night never happened, and you  and I are gonna take this to our  coffins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in love with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta stares at him in alarm, slaps his face, then stud his face to see the effect of the slap. She is dissatisfi and slaps him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snap out of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Then I must never see you  again. The bad blood will have to  stay there between you and Johnny  for all time. You won't come to the  wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come to the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he wants me to come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's cause he don't know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I will not come. Provided  one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you come with me tonight. Once.  To the Opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love two things. I love you, and I  love the Opera. If I can have the  two things that I love together for  one night, I will be satisfied to  give up the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Meet me at the Met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Where's the Met?

dialogues.speaker: CATHOLIC CHURCH IN LITTLE ITALY
dialogues.text: Camera moves from stained glass windows to confessional. Loretta is next in line of THREE SINNERS waiting to go in the confessional. A FORGIVEN WOMAN emerges from the curta booth and walks off to pay her penance. Loretta goes into the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta kneels. The slide opens and an OLD PRIEST'S FACE be seen in outline through the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
