dialogues.text: Bless me, Father, for I have sinned.  It's been two months since my last  confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sins have you to confess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twice I took the name of God in vain,  once I slept with the brother of my  fiancГ©, and once I bounced a check  at the liquor store -- but that was  really an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it was not a sin. But what was  that second thing you said, Loretta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... a... slept with my fiancГ©'s  brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a pretty big sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should think about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. This is your penance. Say  two rosaries and... be careful,  Loretta. Reflect on your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I absolve you in the name of the  Father, and of the Son, and of the  Holy Spirit, Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta comes out of the confessional and enters a pew. S crosses herself. Then she recognizes the back of a woman' head a few pews down. She gets up, walks down the aisle, kneels down next to her mother, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from her  prayers) Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like your father. I lied to  him. He thinks you came home last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo's cheating on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wife knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you don't know. You're just  imagining it. He's too old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose starts to reply, but then decides it's not worth the argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be home for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta crosses herself quickly, gets up, and leaves. Ros looks after, and then goes back to her prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feminine hands apply the final decorative touches of blue icing to a wedding cake. Then the hands set the plastic b and groom on the pinnacle. The CAMERA PULLS BACK. Barbara is viewing her handiwork, a wedding cake on a  stainless steel wheeled cart. She's in the back part of t bakery. Barbara is pleased with her creation. We TRAVEL W HER as she rolls the cart out to the front of the store w Chrissy is waiting on a huge man named HARVEY. She hands a tiny box, which he takes meekly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow, Chrissy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey lumbers off as Barbara enters the front of the sto with the cake on its cart. Barbara calls Chrissy's attent to the cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without enthusiasm) Where's Ronny? How come he ain't  come down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS. Chrissy answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Cammareri's? Hi. Uh-huh. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Ronny. He don't feel good.  He ain't gonna be down today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chrissy comes out from behind the counter. She's staring the cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, is he still upset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without warning, Chrissy whacks the little bride and groo off the cake and on to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara looks at her, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Italian specialty store in Little Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Provolones and salamis hang from above. To the one side i deli counter, to the other a series of tables displaying  cheeses by the pound, packaged cakes, etc. In the back ar few tables and a kitchen with counter. Up front, behind t deli counter, stands Rita Cappomaggi in a blue apron. Out by the tables, Raymond unpacks some jars of olives. I the back, a TRUCK DRIVER can dimly be seen eating his lun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rita) I feel great I got no sleep but I  feel like Orlando Furioso!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks around  cautiously, then  speaks) You were a tiger last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you were a lamb. As soft as milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. They'll hear you in the  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? The pleasure of marriage is  you sleep with the woman and then  you don't worry about nothing. Hey,  how about a date tonight, Rita. Let's  eat pasta and roll around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scandalized) Raymond, Raymond, lower your voice!  What's got into you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! That moon! That crazy  moon Cosmo sent over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there (sings) ...YOU WITH THE STARS IN YOUR EYES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rita) What's the matter with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see that moon last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious and guilty) What about the moon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she lies, nervous) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I gotta go. I'll take the  deposit to the bank but I'll do the  books tomorrow. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about, you fool?  Her fiancГ©'s in Palermo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got things to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do. You got all that wedding  stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's romantic, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...ISN'T IT ROMANTIC...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is walking towards the back now. He shouts to somebody the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEY. Make me a bowl of minestrone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women are left alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? You look crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a lot on my mind, Aunt Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been set up for a church bazaar. There are several w of fortune, many stuffed animals, coffee urns, cakes, a g of ring toss, etc. AS THE CAMERA inventories the contents the various stands -- a LITTLE NUN sleeps in one of them we HEAR the Old Man's VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a lot on my mind. Things  are getting bad in my house. My  daughter-in-law is mad at my son  because he will not pay for the  wedding.

dialogues.speaker: A TUB OF APPLES FLOATING IN WATER
dialogues.text: An old, gnarled hand reaches in and pulls one out, dries with a towel. The CAMERA PULLS BACK REVEALING that the ha belongs to Lucy, who is standing behind a table with the Man and Felix. She hands the apple to the Old Man, who dr a small wooden stake into it with a little wooden hammer. Then the Old Man hands this staked apple to Felix, who di it into a deep metal pot. It emerges shining with red can goo. Then Felix sets the candled apple onto a papered tra where a dozen already sit. They repeat this process. But Old Man, because his thoughts are elsewhere, takes foreve to drive the stake into the apple. This frustrates Felix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At dinner, my daughter-in-law  threatened to kill me. Things are  very bad in my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I hit the stick too hard, the  apple will split. If I am too timid,  the apple will fall off the stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supposed to do fifty apples.  We only got twelve done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to advise my son.  I think he should pay for the wedding,  but it is important that he don't  look ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make yourself sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo drank five glasses of wine at  dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. But I must find the right  moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the moon last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man's eyes light up. He looks at Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in despair) Hurry up, hurry up. We open in five  minutes.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHT NEAT STACKS OF MONEY BEING RUBBERBANDED
dialogues.text: By a woman's hands. The last stack is topped with a fille out deposit slip. The banded stacks are then stuffed into night-deposit bag. The CAMERA PULLS BACK a bit to INCLUDE ledger. A last entry is made, and the ledger is shut. The CAMERA PULLS BACK more, and now WE SEE Loretta reaching f her coat. She puts it on, picks up the deposit bag, and s Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Aunt Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, bye, honey. See you tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll be in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta goes out the door, with Rita looking after,  thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta walks-down the street and comes to the CINDERELLA BEAUTY SHOP, fidgets a moment, looks around to see if  anybody's looking, and goes in. WE SEE her through the window talking to MILDRED, who han appointments. Mildred nods, points, and Loretta goes back into the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE DISCOVER an uneasy Loretta sitting in a beauty chair w BONNIE, her hairdresser about to start. Bonnie is a littl bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? You want the usual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to get rid of the grey.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSFORMATIONAL MUSIC STARTS HERE AND CONTINUES THROUGH
dialogues.text: FOLLOWING SCENES. This music should convey that Loretta i turning from a frumpy pumpkin into a sleek and beautiful  coach. Bonnie wakes up upon hearing this startling news a gets very excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been wanting to do this for  three years! Let me show you some  magazines! You've got to get a  manicure! And your eyebrows! Sheila!  I'm gonna need help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEILA, another beautician, joins Bonnie, and they both g very excited and start showing Loretta and each other  magazines. They argue merrily about what they should do,  leaving Loretta far behind. A MANICURIST joins them, with her stuff and starts soaking Loretta's nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're plucking her eyebrows. They're cutting and dying her hair. They're painting her nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta comes out. Her hair is jet black and done in a mu more stylish way. She looks great. She looks around as if she has committed a crime, and walks off quickly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta looks in the windows, is dissatisfied, and walks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stylish dress shop called INSINUATION. Loretta looks in the window, is intimidated, and walks on. A moment passes She reappears. Tentatively, she enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta approaches a young woman, MER, who works there. M is about thirty, trendily dressed, and French. Mer and Lo greet and talk. Loretta makes vague gestures trying to co what she wants, but the truth is she doesn't know what sh wants. Mer takes the situation in hand. There follows a MONTAGE of Mer showing Loretta various  dresses, some outlandish, some beautiful, some  incomprehensible. Loretta tries on several of the dresses a big triple mirror. Some horrify her, some frighten her  because they're so sexy, one bores her. We don't see the  dress that she ultimately does buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta walks out with a big shopping bag. She walks away down the street. WE FOLLOW Loretta away down the street. She comes to a BR SHOP with a big bride dummy shown off in the window She s and looks at the bride. She walks close to the window and stares in hard. Then she slowly backs up from the bride. Two NUNS are walking by. Loretta, backing up from the dum bumps into the Nuns. She's flustered, makes a brief apolo and hurries away, casting a furtive last glance at the sh window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night is falling. Loretta appears and enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Loretta enters she drops her bag and, as she takes off her coat, calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma! Grandpa! No? Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SINGLE BARK is HEARD from the top of the stairs. She lo up.

dialogues.speaker: A WOODEN ACCORDION GATE SEALS OFF THE TOP OF THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Visible behind the gate are a couple of dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta goes through a door and into the kitchen. She ope the refrigerator and a cabinet, and makes herself a scotc on the rocks. She sips it and starts to HUM in an underst way. She takes her drink and wanders out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA WALKS INTO THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: She walks to each lamp in the room and turns it on. There are many table and standing lamps throughout the room.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA IS LIGHTING THE FIRE
dialogues.text: Which was already built in the fireplace. It catches on  nicely. She puts her drink down and gets a big standing  antique mirror on rollers from its place against the wall She wheels it to a central place in the room. Satisfied, picks up her drink again, leaves the room for a moment, a then returns with her shopping bag. She throws it on a ch Then she goes to the stereo and looks through the albums. She selects one and puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: Loretta waltzes around in front of the mirror, flirting w herself in a very serious way. She starts to unbutton her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon is overhead as music continues to PLAY. The CAME SOARS UP CLOSE to the moon, until it completely FILLS THE FRAME with its magic. The moon dissolves into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP of LORETTA'S FACE as she puts the final touches her make-up. Music continues to PLAY. The CAMERA PULLS BA WE SEE her full figure. She has changed into her evening  dress and put on her heels. She's swaying to the music. T evening dress is sensational. She leans forward and kisse the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: WE SEE THE LIPSTICK KISS ON THE MIRROR
dialogues.text: In the mirror, all around the kiss, is reflected the fire

dialogues.speaker: EXT. EAST RIVER NIGHT
dialogues.text: The moon is reflected in the water as WE SEE the dock of night before. We can SEE Jersey lit up across the river. But then something starts to replace Jersey. It's a huge  white liner coming down the river now, all of her lights  burning, heading back out to sea. FLASHBULBS go off along the deck. We watch the length of the great ship pass as t

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN CENTER
dialogues.text: CROWDS OF PEOPLE in beautiful clothes fill the plaza crea by the three great buildings. A glorious fountain filled  with lights forms the centerpiece. Behind the fountain, g and splendidly lit, is the magical Metropolitan Opera Hou Two huge Chagalls, one to the right and one to the left,  inhabit the face of the building, filling it with marvelo color.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA COMES TO THE FOUNTAIN
dialogues.text: The fountain is quiet and dark now. Loretta is puzzled. She remembers that it was going. While she looks, it ligh up. Then small jets of water begin to appear. Then larger jets. Then with a roar the central shaft of water rises high, h into the night sky. She follows the column of water with eyes up into the sky. Right above the crest of the water, like a beanball on a seal's nose, is the moon.

dialogues.speaker: FROM OVER LORETTA'S SHOULDER WE SEE THE RUSHING WATER
dialogues.text: Forming an opaque wall before her. Then the fountain, for its next piece of aquatic choreography, drops away to not quite suddenly. And there, facing Loretta, on the opposit side of the fountain, is Ronny. He's looking incredibly handsome and dashing in a tuxedo topcoat and, of course, gloves. He smiles slightly and ra a hand in greeting. Loretta, caught off guard, smiles  brilliantly at him. Then she remembers her situation and  starts to put on her usual serious expression. But the  fountain has rushed up into the sky again, obscuring her  attempt at composure from, Ronny. Ronny COMES INTO VIEW again, walking toward Loretta aroun the fountain's perimeter. He comes close to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look beautiful. Your hair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd try it. (qrudgingly) You look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to kiss her. She takes a step back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I'd go to the opera with you.  Nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny immediately relents, gently takes her arm, and they walk off in the direction of the opera house.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE CHAGALL'S FROM IMMEDIATELY IN FRONT OF THE MET
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta looking up at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who painted that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marc Chagall. A Russian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda gaudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was having some fun. Yeah, well  he's dead. (he smiles) Come on, let's go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta join the crowd streaming into the build

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta enter, giving tickets to usher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta checking their coats. Ronny's coat is  already off, and he's helping Loretta off with hers. He h her coat to the CHECKER and pockets the check. Then he tu and sees Loretta in her dress for the first time. He's stunned by her beauty. He's at a loss. He mumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. For your hair. For  your beautiful dress. For... you  know, I feel like a man again. You  know I love the Opera. You know it's  been a long time since I've been to  the Opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are bright with tears. Loretta is touched and st to put her hand out to him. But she stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Where are we sitting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her arm. They pass under the great chandelier an go into the house.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMERA PICKS OUT A SERIES OF COUPLES
dialogues.text: The first couple is PEGGY and CLIVE, a very distinguished pair of silver-haired lovers dressed magnificently. They in their seats, delighted to be where they are, holding h Next is the CELEBRITY COUPLE. Maybe Jackie O and her son, John. They are seated and people are looking at them. Next is Cosmo and Mona. Cosmo is helping Mona to sit down something she could probably handle herself. He's wearing good but old-fashioned suit. She is in a dress that makes her look like a big piece of hard candy. Next is Ronny and Loretta. They are sitting in the first of the First Circle; in other words, very good seats. They are holding their programs. Loretta opens her progra

dialogues.speaker: THE OPEN PROGRAM
dialogues.text: The opera is LA BOHEME. But then the page fades away into the dark as the house lights go down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny leans his head toward her and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the lights come up in the orchestra pit. The CONDUCTOR takes his place. The AUDIENCE APPLAUDS. He bows and turns the orchestra. The OVERTURE begins and PLAYS UNDER NEXT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OVERTURE PLAYS THROUGH this ESTABLISHING SHOT and the FADES AWAY at the start of the NEXT SHOT. WE SEE Rose ent the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dinner crowd is in and most of the tables are occupie The entranceway door opens and Rose enters. She's got herself up very nice. The host, JIMMY, quickly  approaches her. She's very dignified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Castorini. Who's coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just me. I want to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a table for you right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy leads her to a table for two against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seats her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy your meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy breezes off. There's another table-for-two against wall to Rose's front. WE SEE a woman's back from Rose's P and a pretty head of hair. This woman, whose name is SHEI is having an argument with the man across from her. But the man's face is blocked by Sheila's back and head, the argument is too low to be made out. Bobo approaches R table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening Mrs. Castorini. You  eating alone tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Bobo. Yes. Let me have a  martini, no ice and two olives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo heads off for the bar. The couple at the next table  catches Rose's attention again, and their argument become little louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to explain to you how I  feel. Every time I try to explain  how I feel, you explain how you feel.  I don't think that's really much of  a response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, its the only response I've  got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo reappears with the martini and serves it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna see a menu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. I'll wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobo is gone. Rose is mildly intrigued with the argument the next table now. She tries to see past Sheila, to see man, but she can't without making too big a move. The arg goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really do hate it though, when you  take that tone with me. Like you're  above it all and isn't it amusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to me! This is my life, no matter  how damned comical it may seem to  you. I don't need some man standing  above the struggle while I roll around  in the mud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you like the mud and I don't.  That's fair, isn't it? If I don't  care to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheila stands up abruptly and flings a glass of water in man's face. She pulls her coat off the back of her chair stalks off. This whole operation took about two seconds. When she stalks off, the face of the man becomes visible Rose for the first time. It's Perry, the professor in his 50's, who appeared and was treated in a similar way in th earlier scene in this restaurant. His face is covered wit beads of water. He pats his face with his napkin and  apologizes to CUSTOMERS at neighboring tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that, folks. She's a  very pretty mental patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shy Waiter arrives to assist Perry in drying himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind about me. But could you  do me a favor and clear her place  and take away all evidence of her,  and bring me a big glass of vodka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shy Waiter heads for the bar. For the first time, Per notices Rose. They are facing each other with no obstacles in the way n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if we disturbed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not disturbed. By you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lady friend has a personality  disorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was just too young for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shy Waiter serves Perry his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Waiter) Thanks, comrade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Shy Waiter goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Rose's comment strikes  home) Ouch. Too young! I just got that.  You know how to hurt guy. How old  are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops his posturing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. That was rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you join me for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'd be delighted. I hate eating  alone, and it's amazing how often I  end up doing just that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a professor. I teach  communications at N.Y.U.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That woman was a student of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheila? Yes she was. Is. Was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's old saying my mother told  me. Would you like to hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shit where you eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback, then  recovering) I'll remember that. What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a housewife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you eating alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not eating alone. Can I ask you  a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do men chase women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considers) Nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's because they fear death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. Listen. You wanna know why I  chase women? I find women charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I teach these classes I've taught  for a million years. The spontaneity  went out of it for me a long time  ago. I started off, I was excited  about something and I wanted to share  it. Now it's rote, it's the  multiplication table. Except  sometimes. Sometimes I'm droning  along and I look up, and there's  this fresh young beautiful face, and  it's all new to her and I'm this  great guy who's just brilliant and  thinks out loud. And when that  happens, when I look out among those  chairs and look at a young woman's  face, and see me there in her eyes,  me the way I always wanted to be and  maybe once was, then I ask her out  on a date. It doesn't last. It can  go for a few weeks or a couple of  precious months, but then she catches  on that I'm just a burnt out old  gasbag and that she's as fresh and  bright and full of promise as  moonlight in a martini. And at that  moment, she stands up and throws a  glass of water in my face, or some  action to that effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you don't know about women is a  lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERMISSION. THRONGS OF PEOPLE talking, talking, talking Piled up at the bars to get drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the women's bathroom, with its huge line waiting get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta and THREE OTHER WOMEN freshen their makeup before mirror. The woman next to Loretta leaves and is replaced Mona. Mona and Loretta stand side by side freshening thei makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANY PEOPLE pressing to the bar to buy drinks. Cosmo and  Ronny achieve the bar's perimeter at the same moment, and start to order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CONCESSIONAIRE selling special glossy LA BOHEME program

dialogues.speaker: ELSEWHERE IN THE LOBBY DURING INTERMISSION
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta are standing by a column holding drinks Loretta is looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get some turnout for this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the best thing there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like parts of it, but I don't really  get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN ANOTHER PART OF THE LOBBY DURING INTERMISSION Cosmo an Mona are sitting on a bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't once said you like my  dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your dress. (he thinks) It's very bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you looking around so much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I got a feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wearing your bracelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, still looking around.

dialogues.speaker: CHIMES SOUND THROUGHOUT LOBBY
dialogues.text: Indicating the end of intermission. The Audience starts t file back into the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Perry emerge from the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I walk with you a ways?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They set off to the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, and the Old Man comes out, in his great c and hat, with the Five dogs. He strikes off to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Perry come around a corner and pass a store. The pause and look at the Christmas decorations in the window They continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man and the Dogs have stopped by a big tree. Whic the dogs adore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Perry walking. They exit camera left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man drags the Dogs away from the tree and sets of camera right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Perry walking to the left.

dialogues.speaker: EXT . STREET II
dialogues.text: The Old Man and the Dogs walking to the right.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE LAUNDROMAT
dialogues.text: Rose and Perry are walking towards camera. Rose stops sho stunned and alarmed by what she sees before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man pulls up the Dogs. Aghast by what he sees bef him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perry and Rose face the Old Man and the dogs. In a silent standoff. Perry is puzzled, but has the sense say nothing. After a long moment, the Old Man silently st his dogs past them. He walks away down the dark street,  silently disappearing into the gloom. Perry and Rose neve move, but follow his slow progress until he disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAGE
dialogues.text: It's the SCENE in which MIMI is standing in the falling s She SINGS to RUDOLPH. It is a beautiful, poignant moment. The snow is falling, falling. Mimi is SINGING her  heartbreaking aria of farewell. The lighted tavern window behind them, glowing with a golden light.

dialogues.speaker: WE SEE RONNY'S FACE
dialogues.text: He's staring intently at the stage with shining eyes. He  wants to share this moment with Loretta, but he is timid will not feel as he does.

dialogues.speaker: WE SEE LORETTA'S FACE
dialogues.text: A single tear trails down her cheek. Otherwise, she is al succeeding in hiding that the opera is moving her. She no Ronny's hand creeping towards hers, but makes no move tow it.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAGE
dialogues.text: She and Rudolph join hands.

dialogues.speaker: RONNY AND LORETTA
dialogues.text: grab each other's hand fiercely. At last, they look at each other. She is admitting that s is affected by the opera. He is grateful that she admits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audience exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lobby overflowing with the AUDIENCE coming out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta at the coatcheck. Loretta dabs her eyes and blows her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was just so... awful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful. Sad. She died!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving the check to  the checker) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe it! I didn't think  she was going to die. I knew she was  sick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny gets the coats and helps her on with hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had TB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny is putting on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. She was coughing her brains  out. And still, she had to sing all  the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta has stopped suddenly, transfixed by the sight bef her. Loretta and Ronny are standing face-to-face with Cosmo an Mona. Mona's wearing a coat like a wrapper for hard candy Cosmo is wearing his coat and has his hat in his hand. Stunned at seeing Loretta, he unconsciously puts his hat Then he thinks about it and takes it off again. He looks Ronny. Then he looks at Mona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny looks at Loretta. He waits to follow her lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me by the doors, Mona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona obeys after looking curiously at Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pop? What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo approaches Ronny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Loretta's arm and steers her a distance away for confidential exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mona?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you do to your hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this man? You're engaged!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my daughter. I won't have you  acting like a tramp!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I didn't see you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether I saw you or  not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo puts on his hat again. He glares at Ronny. He looks Loretta, but he's at a total loss. At last, he stalks off Loretta looks after him, angry and disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA LOOKING AFTER THEM, STRICKEN
dialogues.text: Ronny appears at her side, solicitous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get outta here. I'll buy you a  drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta, still looking after, slowly shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Perry stand on a sidewalk under a street light d shining. About half a block away stands the Castorini hou They regard it. Over the house hangs the moon, cut throug now with a sharp grey cloud. Rose and Perry's VOICES can heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the whole house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, it's a mansion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in a one-bedroom apartment.  What exactly does your husband do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a plumber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. That explains it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the WIND can be heard rising up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rising cold wind stirs their hair. They both shiver  slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Temperature's dropping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you can't invite me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I think the house is empty. I  can't invite you in because I'm  married and because I know who I am. You're shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a little boy and you like to  be bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could go to my apartment. You  could see how the other half lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too old for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too old for me. That's my  predicament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. Can I kiss you on the  cheek, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm freezing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away, towards the house. Perry, shivering, look after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta sit at the bar. They are just finishing couple of Old-Fashions. The barman, AL, inspects their dr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Old-Fashion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Al) I think that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al nods and walks off. Ronny leans forward to Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta are walking. Their breath is coming out long plumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It smells like snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence for a moment, then Loretta speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother guessed that my father was  seeing somebody and I told her she  was crazy. She looked like a real  piece of cheap goods. But who am I  to talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes are full of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you ask me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making me feel guilty again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are guilty. I'm guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what? Only God can point the  finger, Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you know? You tell me my  life? I'll tell you yours. I'm a  wolf? You run to the wolf in me,  that don't make you no lamb! You're  gonna marry my brother? Why you wanna  sell your life short? Playing it  safe is just about the most dangerous  thing a woman like you could do. You  waited for the right man the first  time, why didn't you wait for the  right man again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks. It's Ronny's building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where we're going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deal was if I came to the Opera  with you you'd leave me alone forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks for his response. He makes none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went with you. (pause, nothing) Now I'm gonna marry Johnny and you're  gonna leave me alone. (pause, nothing) Right? (nothing) A person can see where they've messed  up in their life, and they can change  how they do things, and they can  change their Luck. Maybe my nature  does draw me to you, but I don't  haveta go with that. I can take hold  of myself and say yes to some things  and no to something that's just gonna  ruin everything! I can do that.  Otherwise, what is this stupid life  that God gave us for what? (pause, nothing) Ronny? Are you listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid of who I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're not now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Everything seems like  nothing now against that I want you  in my bed. I don't care if I burn in  hell. I don't care if you burn in  hell. The Past and Future is a joke  to me now. I see that they're nothing,  I see they ain't here. The only thing  that's here is you. And me. I want  you to come upstairs. Now. I tried  to take everything last night, like  you told me, but I couldn't. I  couldn't take everything in a hundred  years. It's the way we are. We  compound each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm freezing to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come upstairs. I don't care why you  come. No, that's not what I mean.  Loretta, I love you. Not like they  told you love is and I didn't know  this either. But love don't make  things nice, it ruins everything, it  breaks your heart, it makes things a  mess. We're not here to make things  perfect. Snowflakes are perfect. The  stars are perfect. Not us. We are  here to ruin ourselves and break our  hearts and love the wrong people and  die! The storybooks are bullshit.  Come upstairs with me, baby! Don't  try to live your life out to somebody  else's idea of sweet happiness. Don't  try to live on milk and cookies when  what you want is meat! Red meat just  like me! It's wolves run with wolves  and nothing else! You're a wolf just  like me! Come upstairs with me and  get in my bed! Come on! Come on!  Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta follows Ronny into his building.

dialogues.speaker: NOW WE SEE THE STREET
dialogues.text: Just as the door shuts. A moment passes. Lights go on in  Ronny's apartment. Out of a doorway on the opposite side the street steps the figure of a woman. She walks to the  middle of the deserted street and looks up at the lighted windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her heart is about to break. She loves this man. She look up at the lighted windows, her feelings hanging by one  slender, slender thread.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: It's "MIMI'S ARIA"- from the snow scene in LA BOHEME.

dialogues.speaker: WE SEE THE STREET WITH THE FIGURE LOOKING
dialogues.text: At the lighted window above. "MIMI'S ARIA" PLAYS. This ta reminds us of the scene in the opera where MIMI stands in the snow. The MUSIC PLAYS and the WOMAN SINGS for a long  moment. Then, the lights in the apartment go out. Chrissy shudders almost imperceptibly. Her heart has broken. She  hangs her head. Then she lifts her head and slowly walks  away down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a great and abrupt ROAR, a big jet is landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASSENGERS are pouring into the terminal from the plane. Most of them are Italian or Italian-Americans. Suddenly, Johnny appears out of the shifting crowd, up very CLOSE t the CAMERA. He looks alert, determined, geared up for act

dialogues.speaker: MR. JOHNNY AT THE LUGGAGE CAROUSEL
dialogues.text: He pulls his two suitcases off the carousel with one quic powerful jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny sticks out his hand and a cab immediately rush to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny leans forward to the DRIVER and says in a very definite, determined way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 Cranberry Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab rushes off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab pulling up to the Castorini house. The living roo windows are all lit up. VICKI CARR can be made out SINGIN "IT MUST BE HIM". Mr. Johnny gets out of the cab, gets hi luggage, and heads for the front door. He RINGS THE BELL. The door opens. It's Rose. MUSIC floods out around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. I'm sorry to call so late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is a little tipsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came right from the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds the door open for him and he goes in past her  carrying his suitcases. She closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you wake up Loretta? I need to  talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not home yet. Take off your  coat and come in the living room.  I'll make you a drink. I wanna talk  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose comes in with two scotches on the rocks. He takes on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns off the stereo, and then sits down across from  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out. I don't know where. I was waiting  up for my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a pause. Mr. Johnny is uncomfortable with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? You're  supposed to be in Palermo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I came to tell Loretta.  There's been a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A miracle. Well, that's news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother's recovered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The breath had almost totally left  her body. She was as white as snow.  And then she completely pulled back  from death and stood up and put on  her clothes and began to cook for  everyone in the house. The mourners.  And me. And herself! She ate a meal  that would choke a pig!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door can be HEARD SLAMMING, out of view, and th Dogs can be HEARD BARKING. Mr. Johnny and Rose look to th entranceway. The Old Man appears there, holding the Five  Dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man looks at Rose. He is a specter. He stares, an then he makes a long low accusing NOISE. Then he disappea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my father-in-law, who has a  wrong idea in his head. Listen,  Johnny, there's a question I want to  ask you. And I want you to tell me  the truth if you can. Why do men  chase women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. There's the Bible story. God  took a rib from Adam and made Eve.  Maybe men chase women to get the rib  back. When God took the rib, he left  a hole there, place where there used  to be something. and the women have  that. Maybe a man isn't complete as  a man without a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why would a man need more than  one woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe because he fears  death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose leaps up, very excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it! That's the reason!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's really it. Thank you for  answering my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FRONT DOOR SLAMS again. Mr. Johnny and Rose look to t entranceway. Cosmo appears there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. (taking in Mr. Johnny) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Castorini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Rose. I don't know  where I've been, and I don't know  where I'm going. (to Mr. Johnny) You should have your eyes opened for  you, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have my eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do, huh? Stick around. Don't go  on any long trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you don't. That's the point.  I'll say no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't said anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's how much I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want you to know. No matter  what you do. You are going to die,  just like everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to bed now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny stands up. Cosmo walks off, out of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from top of stairs) Good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mr. Johnny) He doesn't like you. Thank you for  answering my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know where Loretta is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then tell her I'll come by in the  morning. We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch the effect of the sun coming up on the house. It begins in darkness, and goes through the many graduations light very quickly until it's lit by the light of bright  morning.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR OPENS AND THE OLD MAN AND THE DOGS COME OU
dialogues.text: He's got them on their leashes and, over his head, he car the black umbrella. He walks off toward the park and  disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along a sidewalk a couple of blocks away. She is a wreck. She's still in her clothes of the night before. She hasn' slept. Her hair's a bit funny. And she's tormented by the complications in her life. And, at the same time, she loo great. She looks like she's been loved up and down. She h a hickey on her neck. Her eyes are dreamy and her walk is slow, utterly careless, and sexual. She's carrying, crunc in her hand, her program from La Boheme. She starts SINGI We follow her as she SINGS and walks.

dialogues.speaker: WE WATCH LORETTA WALKING FROM THE BACK NOW
dialogues.text: She's still muttering. She comes to a tin can. She kicks She comes to it again. She kicks it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta appears kicking her can. She abandons the can and enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is at the stove. The kitchen is filled with steam an sunlight. Rose is stirring a pot filled with oatmeal. Another range has the coffeepot heating. Loretta shuffles into the kitchen, goes to the tin table, and sits down. There are red roses on the table. Rose sees Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I don't really know where to  start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hair's different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I have a hangover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's pop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs. Johnny Cammareri showed up  last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta is suddenly electrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He's in Sicily!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more he's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's with his dying mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She recovered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT!! She was dying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A miracle? This is modern times!  There ain't supposed to be miracles  any more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it ain't modern times in  Sicily. He came right from the  airport. He wanted to talk to you.  You got a love bite on your neck.  He's coming back this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a long low MOAN, Loretta lowers her head to the tabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny is walking along the same stretch of sidewalk as Lo just was. He looks like hell, too. His hair is wild and h hasn't slept. He's thrown on an old leather jacket and br leather gloves. He has a love bite on his neck, too. He s to SING "O SOAVE FANCIULLA". He SINGS it any old way,  occasionally getting a good attack, occasionally just  muttering his way through. SINGS as much of it as he  remembers, which is a lot.

dialogues.speaker: WE WATCH RONNY WALKING FROM THE BACK NOW
dialogues.text: He's SINGING away, carelessly sauntering along. He passes ITALIAN COUPLE of middle age. They smile as they recogniz what he is singing. They start to SING along with him. They SING till they get to the ceiling of the aria, and t resting place a little beyond. Then they nod to each othe appreciatively and go on their ways, Ronny turning his ba to the CAMERA, and they WALKING INTO IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny appears and approaches the door. HE KNOCKS, waits, then RINGS THE BELL. Rose answers the door and invites hi in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose walks in with Ronny behind her. There's no one in th kitchen. Rose calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta comes out of a closet, where she was hiding. She' very surprised to see Ronny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Johnny here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! We can get this out on the  table. (to Rose) I'm Ronny, Johnny's brother. (Shakes her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. You've got a love  bite on your neck. Your mother's  recovered from death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Good. We're not close. I'm not  really moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've gotta get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm gonna wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (arguing with Ronny) Ronny, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would anyone like some oatmeal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORETTA continues arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignores Loretta) Yes, I would like some oatmeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta sit down and Rose serves them oatmeal. COSMO WALKS IN dressed for business. He regards the trio, puts on his hat in shock and then takes it off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo, this is Ronny, Johnny's  brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo sits down. Rose puts a bowl of oatmeal in front of  him. He absently begins to eat it. A silence reigns. Then puls down his spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Johnny's brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosmo picks up his spoon and they all eat silently once m The SOUND OF DOGS BARKING comes up and then fades away.

dialogues.speaker: THE OLD MAN WALKS IN
dialogues.text: He looks at the assemblage. The assemblage looks at him. He points at Rose. Then his pointing drifts to Cosmo and hand opens in a gesture of supplication.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am old. The Old are not wanted.  And what they say has no weight.  But, my son, I must speak. You should  pay for the wedding of your only  daughter. You are breaking your house  through pride. There. I've said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Pop. If she gets married,  I'll pay for the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man lets go a great noise of relief, sits down at the table, and waits. Rose brings him a bowl of oatmeal. He is content now, and eats his oatmeal with great relish The others eat with a more meaningful silence. Rose puts  down her spoon. She looks at the table, but she is speaki to Cosmo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I been a good wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to stop seeing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stops eating. A tremendous silence falls. An old clock goes tick, tick, tick. Suddenly Cosmo smashes his f to the table and stands. He doesn't look at Rose during t Then slowly, he sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And go to confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still not looking at  her) A man... under stands one day...  that his life is built on nothing.  And that's a bad, crazy day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your life is not built on nothing.  Ti amo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hand across the table to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ti amo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides his hand out and takes her hand. Slowly, he lif his eyes. Their eyes meet. It's the first time he's been  able to hold her gaze in this whole story. The DOORBELL R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Johnny. I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta's tone is fatal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to answer the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goes for the door) No, I'll tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'll tell him. (to her father) What am I going to tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him the truth, Loretta they  find out anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta looks at her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you Pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a private moment. But who appears at the kitchen door is not Johnny. It's t CAPPOMAGGIS. They have their coats on and they look very serious and  concerned and timid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Why ain't you at the store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything you want to tell  us, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just come from the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bank. OH MY GOD, I FORGOT TO  MAKE THE DEPOSIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Raymond) She's got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew she had it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta runs out of the kitchen and reappears with her  everyday bag. She takes out the night deposit bag and han it to Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't know what to think. You  were so weird yesterday, and then  this morning, we go to the bank and  no bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sudden outburst to  Loretta) WE NEVER SUSPECTED YOU!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond covers his face to hide his emotion. Rita, meanwh is clearing the oatmeal bowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. Who wants coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a general acknowledgment. Everybody wants coffee Rose passes out white mugs and begins pouring steaming dr of coffee. Raymond and Rita are standing. The rest are  sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're waiting for Johnny Cammareri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita nods. A silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking and shaking  his hand) Nice to meet you. I'm Rita Cappomaggi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking and taking  his hand) I'm Raymond Cappomaggi. I'm Rose's  brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then the Old Man erupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody tell a joke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORBELL RINGS. And RINGS AGAIN. Everyone is frozen f a moment, then Rita mobilizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes. Loretta puts down her coffee and deep breathes, preparing herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting palpitations!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushes away her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was in Palermo.

dialogues.speaker: RITA APPEARS WITH MR. JOHNNY IN TOW
dialogues.text: Rita continues into the room, leaving Mr. Johnny in the  doorway. He is in a dark, vested suit. He is a little  bewildered by the crowd of people, but succeeds in hiding most of his discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Johnny Cammareri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny! Our mother has recovered from  death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you come to make peace with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Yeah. You may not want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But Johnny, how did  your mother recover? She was dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should talk alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I need my family around me  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I told my mother that we were  to be married. And she got well.  Right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure she did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a miracle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, I have something to tell  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something to tell you. But I  must talk to you alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no secrets from my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta, I can't marry you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I marry you my mother will die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man laughs a loud sudden laugh, and then subsides

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?  We're engaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta, what are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about a promise. You  proposed to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my mother was dying! But now  she's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're forty-two years old, Johnny,  and Mama is still running your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are a son who doesn't love  his mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're a big liar! I've got your  ring here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must ask for that back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta struggles and pulls off the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here! Take your stupid pinky ring. (she throws it at  Johnny) Who needs it? The engagement's off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny retrieves the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In time, you will see that this is  the best thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In time, you will drop dead, and I  will come to your funeral in a red  dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you marry me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the ring?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny looks to Mr. Johnny a little sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I a... borrow that ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny, in shock, hands it over to Ronny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kneels down before Loretta. He presents the ring to he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you marry me, Loretta Castorini  Clark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before all these people, yes, I will  marry you, Ronny Cammareri!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the ring. Ronny and Loretta kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love him, Loretta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Ma, I love him awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, that's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronny and Loretta enter into a long kiss. The Old Man sta to cry. Cosmo leans forward to the Old Man solicitously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Pop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Lifts his head and  cries out) I'M CONFUSED !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta pushes Ronny away, breaking the kiss. They have b neglected to breathe the whole time they were kissing. They are both gasping for air, especially Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then she looks at Ronny, and lunges back to him, divi into another kiss like a mermaid diving into the bluest o

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC
dialogues.text: "O SOAVE FANCIULLA" from "La Boheme," COMES UP and engulf the lovers, the family, the world. WE SEE the faces of the lovers swirl away into a golden a diamond light, and

dialogues.speaker: EIGHT FULL CHAMPAGNE GLASSES
dialogues.text: Glistening in sunlight on the white tabletop. Into each i dropped a lump of sugar. A bottle of recently employed bi sits nearby with its cap off (like a respectful peasant i aristocratic company. And the roses in the center. Now the CAMERA PULLS BACK. WE SEE the table is surrounded Cosmo is dropping the last of the sugar cubes in the last glass of champagne. Rose is by him. Rita and Raymond are  side by side, as are Ronny and Loretta. The Old Man sits, staring at his son, intent and approving. But where is Mr Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody take a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody takes a glass. The Old Man takes one and gets u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cosmo) Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man takes the glass and walks over to a corner of the kitchen where Mr. Johnny, deeply disturbed and somewh catatonic, sits on a step-ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Mr.  Johnny, offering the  glass) Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the Old Man, wise and merry and tough, presses the gl on Mr. Johnny, who takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To... the family. Right? Ti amo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all lift their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ti amo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And looking into each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knocks back his drink lustily, and then with a glitte eye looks away from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnny sits without moving, holding his glass. A long moment passes. Mr. Johnny is thinking. Then he nods to  himself. He lifts his glass and murmurs for no one to hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he laughs his laugh. This laugh could kill him. The C PULLS BACK a little. He pounds the table and knocks over roses.
